head.title: Vegetable Dishes Requiring Little or No Cooking

hedline.hl1: Vegetable Dishes Requiring Little or No Cooking

block.p: IN peak season, farmstand-fresh vegetables often stand on their own. In each of these salads, they're used fresh, with minimal cooking, and given a touch of tangy flavor with a light vinaigrette and a bit of cheese. The cheese also fortifies the various mixtures enough to make them suitable first courses. But beyond that, the preparation is simple, permitting the vegetables to shine.

What cooking there is involves quickly searing eggplant and zucchini on the grill for one, and softening fresh corn and chanterelles in a saute pan for another. The third calls for no cooking at all. It's only important that the vegetables be truly fresh: the tomatoes tender and juicy, the corn just picked, the cucumbers unwaxed and the zucchini shiny and firm.

Grilled Eggplant And Zucchini Panzanella Total time: 40 minutes

1 medium eggplant, about 3/4 pound, sliced 1/2-inch thick 2 medium zucchini, about 3/4 pound, halved legnthwise 1 6-inch piece French or Italian bread, crusts removed 2 large cloves garlic, split 1 1/2 pounds ripe tomatoes, coarsely chopped
1/2 cup chopped Vidalia onion
1/3 cup red-wine vinegar 5 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil 2 tablespoons slivered fresh basil leaves Salt and freshly ground black pepper 1 cup dry goat cheese, crumbled.
1. Preheat grill or broiler. Grill or broil eggplant slices and zucchini halves until nicely seared, turning once to brown both sides. Coarsely chop eggplant and zucchini and set aside.
2. Slice bread half an inch thick and lightly toast slices on the grill or under broiler. Rub each slice with the cut side of the garlic. Dice bread and mince garlic.

3. Combine tomatoes, onion, eggplant and zucchini in a bowl. Add minced garlic. Fold in vinegar and olive oil. Fold in bread, mixing well so it becomes moistened with vinegar, oil and juice of tomatoes. Fold in basil and season salad with salt and pepper. Set aside at least half an hour before serving. Top with goat cheese and serve.
Yield: 6 servings.
Corn and Chanterelle Salad Total time: 30 minutes
6 ears corn on the cob

1/2 pound small exotic mushrooms, preferably chanterelle 8 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil 1 medium-size red onion, sliced thin 4 tablespoons sherry vinegar Salt and freshly ground black pepper 2 bunches fresh arugula, rinsed, dried and stems removed 1 1/2 ounces Parmigiano-Reggiano, in thin shavings.
1. Strip the kernels off the cob and set aside.

2. Wipe any dirt from chanterelles with damp paper towel and cut any large ones in half or quarters. If using shiitake mushrooms, remove and discard stems and cut caps in half-inch slices. If using small cremini, quarter them.

3. Heat six tablespoon oil in large, heavy skillet. Add onion and saute over medium heat until wilted. Stir in mushrooms, increase heat to high and cook mushrooms until softened and moist looking. Stir in corn and three tablespoons vinegar and simmer mixture for a minute or two. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Set aside, off heat, until ready to serve.

4. To serve, toss arugula leaves with remaining vinegar and oil. Arrange on each of six salad plates. Briefly reheat the corn mixture and spoon over arugula. Scatter some cheese on each portion and serve.
Yield: 6 servings.
Tomato and Feta Salad Total time: 20 minutes
2 pounds ripe tomatoes, cored and peeled 2 cucumbers, peeled
1/3 cup thinly sliced fresh fennel
1/2 pound feta cheese, in 3/4-inch chunks
1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil Juice of 1 lemon
1/4 cup diced, pitted kalamata olives 1 tablespoon drained capers Generous pinch hot red pepper flakes Freshly ground black pepper
1/4 cup finely minced fresh basil.
1. Dice tomatoes into three-fourth-inch pieces. Put in a bowl. Quarter cucumbers lengthwise, scoop out seeds and slice three-fourth-inch thick. Put in bowl with fennel and feta.
2. Add oil, lemon juice, olives, capers and red and black pepper. Gently fold all ingredients together.
3. Allow to marinate about an hour at room temperature. Add basil, toss gently, then serve.
Yield: 6 servings.
